title: How to Make Homemade Gluten‐Free Beer

steps.headline: Buy the raw buckwheat.
steps.description: Go to a health food store, brewing supply store, or local co-op and buy one pound (453 g) of raw buckwheat. It shouldn't be cooked or toasted. If you don't want to malt your own buckwheat, you might be able to buy it from your brewing supply store. You'll need to buy three pounds (1.36 kg) of malted buckwheat before you can begin brewing the beer.

steps.headline: Rinse the buckwheat and soak it for 30 to 48 hours.
steps.description: Place the raw buckwheat in a fine mesh strainer in the sink. Rinse the buckwheat. Transfer the buckwheat to a large bowl or plastic tub and fill the container with enough water to completely cover the buckwheat. Soak the buckwheat for 30 to 48 hours. Since the buckwheat will make an oily liquid as it soaks, try to scoop up and rinse the buckwheat every eight hours.

steps.headline: Strain and rinse the buckwheat for two days.
steps.description: Set the fine mesh strainer in the sink and pour the soaked buckwheat through it so the water drains. Place the strainer with the buckwheat in a cool, dark place for two days. Bring the strainer back to the sink and rinse the buckwheat every eight hours during this time. You should see the buckwheat begin to sprout little roots.

steps.headline: Bake the buckwheat for eight to ten minutes.
steps.description: Preheat the oven to 200 degrees F (90 degrees C). Get out a few rimmed baking sheets and spread the buckwheat across them. Put the sheets in the oven and bake the buckwheat for eight to ten minutes. The buckwheat should turn hard, golden, and crisp.

steps.headline: Crush the buckwheat.
steps.description: Remove the baking sheets and cool the buckwheat completely. Transfer the buckwheat to a few seal able plastic bags. Take a rolling pin and crush the buckwheat.

steps.headline: Sanitize the brewing equipment.
steps.description:
Buy a package of no-rinse cleanser and measure one tablespoon (0.5 ounce) of the cleanser into a large bucket. Pour one gallon (3.8 liters) of water into the bucket and stir to dissolve the cleanser. Dip your brewing equipment into the cleanser and lift it out. Let it dry for five minutes before you use the equipment. You'll need to sanitize your:
6.5 gallon (24.5 liter) primary fermenter
Lid
Airlock
Hydrometer
Heat-tolerant spoon
Wort chiller

steps.headline: Combine the malted buckwheat with water.
steps.description: Get out a stainless steel or enamel pot that's at least 12 quarts or 11 liters in size. Set a strainer bag in the pot and place the crushed, malted buckwheat into it. Tie the end of the bag closed. Pour 1 1/2 gallons (5.7 liters) of water into the pot with the buckwheat.

steps.headline: Stir and heat the buckwheat until it boils.
steps.description: Stir the water with the bag of buckwheat and turn the heat to medium-high. Keep stirring the mixture until the water begins to boil. Turn off the heat to stop the water from boiling.

steps.headline: Remove the buckwheat and stir in the syrup, some of the corn sugar, and some of the hops.
steps.description: Lift the bag of buckwheat up and out of the water so the water drains out of the bag. You can throw away the bag. Stir in 1 cup (227 g) of the corn sugar, 6 pounds (2.7 kg) of rice syrup, 1/2 ounce (14 g) of the Saaz hops, and 1/2 ounce (14 g) of the Hallertauer hops. You'll add the remaining hops during the brewing process. Avoid squeezing the bag of buckwheat when you remove it.

steps.headline: Boil the wort for 30 minutes and add more of the hops.
steps.description: Turn the heat on the mixture (now called wort) on to medium-high and stir it frequently. Boil the wort for 30 minutes. Then stir in 1/4 ounce (7 g) of the Saaz hops and 1/4 ounce (7 g) of the Hallertauer hops.

steps.headline: Boil the wort for 15 more minutes and add more of the hops.
steps.description: Continue to stir the wort occasionally as it boils for 15 more minutes. Add the last 1/4 ounce (7 g) of the Saaz hops and another 1/4 ounce (7 g) of the Hallertauer hops.

steps.headline: Boil the wort for another 15 minutes and add the last of the Hallertauer hops.
steps.description: Boil the wort for 15 more minutes while you stir it every once in a while. Stir in the last ounce (28 g) of Hallertauer hops. Turn off the heat and let the hops steep for two minutes. The wort will boil for a total of one hour before you strain it.

steps.headline: Cool the wort.
steps.description:
To quickly chill the wort, insert a wort chiller directly into the wort. Connect the tube to a water tap and turn on the cold water. The cold water will run through the tubing in the wort and back out into the sink/
If you don't have a wort chiller, you can set the pot with the wort into a large bowl of ice water.

steps.headline: Siphon the wort into the primary fermenter.
steps.description: Get out five feet (1.5 meters) of siphoning tube and insert it into the wort. Siphon the wort into the sterilized 6.5 gallon (24.5 liter) primary fermenter. Attach a liquid crystal strip thermometer to the outside so you can check the temperature of the beer as it ferments. You can throw out the sediment or solids that are left in the bottom of the pot.

steps.headline: Add water to the fermenter and stir in the yeast.
steps.description: Pour in enough lukewarm water to the primary fermenter so the liquids reach five gallons (19 liters). Ensure that the liquid in the fermenter isn't higher than 70 degrees F (20 degrees C). Stir in 1 package (11 g) of Danstar ale yeast and mix it until the yeast is combined with the liquid.

steps.headline: Seal the fermenter and attach an air lock.
steps.description: Put the lid on the airlock and press down to seal it tightly. Your lid should have a grommet so you can easily push the airlock into it. Fill the airlock halfway with fresh water to prevent air from coming into contact with the beer as it ferments.

steps.headline: Store the beer in a warm, dry place for ten days.
steps.description: Place the fermenter in a warm part of your house to encourage fermentation. The temperature of the beer should be kept between 68 and 72 degrees F (20 and 22 degrees C). Avoid storing the beer in a bright space. The beer will need to ferment for about ten days. You should see bubbling in the airlock within a day or two of starting the fermentation process. Don't worry if it stops bubbling after several days.

steps.headline: Sanitize the bottling equipment.
steps.description:
Open a package of no-rinse cleanser and measure one tablespoon (0.5 ounce) of the cleanser into a large bucket. Pour one gallon (3.8 liters) of water into the bucket and stir to dissolve the cleanser. Simply dip the bottling equipment into the cleanser. Lift the equipment out and let it dry for five minutes. You'll need to sanitize:
53 twelve-ounce (355 ml) beer bottles
53 bottle caps
Siphon tubing
6.5 gallon (24.5 liter) bottling bucket and spigot
Bottle filling wand

steps.headline: Dissolve the corn sugar in water and boil it for five minutes.
steps.description: Pour the remaining 3/4 cup (170 g) of corn sugar into a saucepan. Stir in two cups (475 ml) of water and turn the heat to high. Bring the water to a boil and stir to dissolve the corn sugar. This should take about five minutes. Turn off the heat and cool the corn sugar. The dissolved corn sugar is known as priming sugar. This will carbonate the beer.

steps.headline: Combine the priming sugar with the beer and siphon it into bottles.
steps.description: Siphon the beer to the sterilized bottling bucket and pour in the cooled priming sugar. Stir the mixture well and insert the siphoning tube into the spigot on the bottling bucket. Attach the other end of the tube to the bottle filling wand. Fill each bottle and leave 1-inch (2.5 cm) of space at the top. Put the caps on the bottles.

steps.headline: Rest the bottled beer for one week.
steps.description: Put the bottles in a dry, dark place for one week. During this time the beer will become carbonated. Keep the bottles in an area that's between 65 and 75 degrees F (18 and 23 degrees C). After one week, you can chill the beer and drink it.
